reviewText: I hope if Andras Schiff ever makes use of an online dating service, he doesn't upload a 20-year-old photo of himself :) It could cause problems!  Here it is not only unnecessary, it could be cutting into sales.  People might not want to purchase a vintage video (yes, I was truly expecting a fuzzy image with suboptimal sound) ... and thereby miss out on a clear, sharp, extremely well-done modern recording (from 2008).Andras Schiff and his orchestra turn in fine performances.  I will note that they are generally a modern instrument group with the exception of a pair of (evidently) original valveless trumpets.  What the intent of that is I am not immediately aware, but I'm sure it was not an accident.  It is essentially a current, modern, standard style of performance, thank goodness, colored very slightly with "awareness" of historic practice (the strings do back off from vibrato in some areas).Schiff conducts as well as plays the Mozart concerto, and when he is playing rather than conducting, group ensemble is within acceptable limits.His conducting career came after several decades of being a world-class pianist, and it shows in his conducting technique.  His gestures are sparse, clear, and concise.  He did not have to build his ego and reputation on an exaggerated technique.I'm not sure I agree with using the Overture to Don Giovanni as a prelude to the D Minor concerto, but if he would like to do that, it's fine :) The biggest quibble I have is with his cadenzas.  The first movement cadenza is strange.  I suppose I can come to understand it after a few more hearings.  The third movement cadenza is a late Romantic paraphrase on the Don Giovanni overture, and it ends far too abruptly.  I really will have to give it a few more listens to hopefully appreciate.  Still, I would not deduct any stars.And I normally would rather not hear Bach done following Mozart, or any music seriously out of chronological order.  But in this instance, the Bach Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue is done as an encore, with the orchestra watching.  No apologies are necessary ... it is masterful.Beautiful, clear sound, and intelligent camera work throughout.  In short, highly recommended.
summary: Despite cover photo, it's a recent recording.

reviewText: András Schiff's 2008 concert with the "Cappella Andrea Barca" (see the explanation for his ensemble's name in Schiff's intelligent bonus monologue on this disk) was recorded live in excellent audio and video in the beautiful Teatro Olimpico in Vicenza. The "Haffner" Symphony comes off very well, spirited, festive and radiant. No repeats are taken. Schiff's chamber orchestra musicians play with much gusto and finesse, and there is a cordial rapport among the team. Apart from the trumpets, no period instruments are used, but with sparing vibrato and lean, transparent textures these performances stand with today's finest. A highly dramatic overture to "Don Giovanni" - I never heard it played better - sets the mood for an equally gripping, incisive performance of the darkly passionate D minor Piano Concerto with perfect interaction between the soloist and the various orchestral voices. Schiff's virtuoso stature is obvious (listen to the enormous cadenzas), but his musicality comes to the fore just as much in the lyrical passages of the second movement Romance. As an encore, he plays Bach's Chromatic Fantasia and Fugue in D minor brilliantly to an enthusiastic audience. This is a DVD to take to the proverbial desert island.

reviewText: This is a most enjoyable concert with mainstream performances given with full awareness of current performing thinking. The orchestra is conducted or led from the piano by Schiff and is of moderate size as appropriate. The type of instruments used is modern with the exception of the trumpets which are of authentic type without valves and which are the sort that Mozart would have recognised. They are inherently less powerful than modern instruments so they can play louder and achieve the required cutting edge of tone without overpowering the rest of the orchestra. This is becoming quite a common practice and can be seen / heard in the performances of Harnoncourt and Mackerras to name just two.The concert starts with a cleanly delivered performance of the 35th symphony given with all the sensitivity one would expect from Schiff who keeps everything within the appropriate scale. Speeds and dynamics fall very much within the appropriate parameters that supporters of the authentic movement would expect.The symphony is followed by the Don Giovanni Overture which then leads directly, without a pause, into the concerto. Schiff explains in his very engaging 'bonus' talk that he has long wanted to pair these two works as he feels they share the same emotional world and one where the overture forms a natural setting for the concerto which is, of course, one of Mozart's more dramatic piano concertos and in the dramatic key of d minor.This pairing does indeed work well in practice, if a little surprising. This is a 'classical' performance of the concerto which does not stray into the 'romantic' period. The temptation to overplay the more emotional aspects is resisted and the performance is compellingly satisfying within the classical concept. The one surprise is the cadenza which is not the one we would expect but is one of the pianist's own creation. There is a generous encore in the form of Bach's Chromatic fantasia and Fugue which is much appreciated by the enthusiastic audience.There is a 14 minute bonus held in the Teatro Olimpico which was created in the  1580's by Palladio and which Schiff finds to be ideal for music of this period and for drama. He describes many things apart from the building and ranges over his love of chamber music and the changing roles of conductors over the years. This is a delightful 'chat' to camera and shows him to be a gentle man with gentle tastes.The recording is presented with good surround sound in DD 5.1 and DTS 5.1 as well as stereo. The imaging is sharp and the camera work is nicely sympathetic to the music, players and setting.This is an uncontentious issue of considerable quality presented in a quiet and thoughtful manner. It should give purchasers considerable satisfaction therefore and seems to me to be well worth the full 5 star rating.
summary: An excellent disc of Mozart favourites which will be hard to improve upon
